text:
Importing arrays using `readdlm` and using `pop!` to ensure an even number of points.

This may be an issue with the source text file. The issue only occurs when I copy/modify the source file to truncate its length.

text: `pop!(::Vector{Float64})` can't modify the vector eltype, there's no way. The problem is elsewhere in your code.

elements.text: can't modify the vector eltype, there's no way. The problem is elsewhere in your code.

text: Yeah, I'm convinced of that now.  It's likely in the `readdlm` step after I copy/modify the source text file.

text:
Simply deleting a few rows from a 2-column text file of Float64 causes the issue. I tried specifying `Float64` type in the `readdlm` function and it produces the error:
```ErrorException("file entry \"\" cannot be converted to Float64")```
Perhaps this is not the easiest way to truncate a time/signal data file as I expected.
